facts.text: Appellant was employee of respondent Company working as Coal Ash Supervisor in Coal and Bardana section.
On morning of April 24, 1963, appellant on duty to sign and issue slips to company tractors for removal of company ash on donkeys outside premises.
Company suspected malpractice by appellant in issuing slips; suspended him and issued charge-sheet dated April 26, 1963.

Charge-sheet alleged appellant issued gate pass to Bhagirath on April 24, 1963 for 48 donkey loads of company ash; gave eight more slips on April 25, 1963 for additional material; Bhagirath caught removing extra goods at gate.
Appellant charged under Standing Order No. 12 for dishonesty in connection with Company's business/property; asked to show cause why not dismissed.
Appellant replied on April 29, 1963 denying dishonesty; pleaded enormous rush of work, possible mistake/inadvertence in issuing additional slips; requested withdrawal of charge-sheet.
Enquiry held; appellant discharged from service w.e.f. May 15, 1963 on payment of one month's salary in lieu of notice; order dated May 3, 1963 found deliberate issuance of extra slips.
Appellant sent Approach Notice dated July 26, 1963 under proviso to Section 31(3) of MP Industrial Relations Act, 1960 requesting reconsideration and reinstatement.
Company replied declining reconsideration.

Appellant filed application before Labour Court, Ujjain under Section 31(3) as Case No. 17 of 1963 Labour challenging discharge order on grounds: unauthorised inquiry, order not by Manager, refusal to produce documents, mala fides, victimisation for union activities.
Company denied mala fides, victimisation; stated inquiry by competent persons, order by competent authority.

Labour Court order dated February 25, 1966: no mala fides/victimisation; inquiry proper by authorised officers; appellant responsible for non-production of slips; plea of mistake rejected; misconduct not fully proved but strong suspicion, honesty doubted; order invalid as not signed by Manager and slips not produced; awarded 5 months salary + 1 month notice pay; no reinstatement.
Company filed Revision No. 46/MPIR/66; workman filed Revision No. 50/MPIR/66 before Industrial Court MP under Sections 66/67.

Industrial Court order dated September 27, 1966: accepted Company's revision, dismissed workman's; discharge order valid, signed by competent authorities (Bhagrodia and Abde Ali); no infirmity in inquiry, full opportunity given, no prejudice from non-production of slips.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court against Industrial Court orders.
Appellant requested production of gate passes/slips on May 2, 1963 for cross-examination; rejected as witnesses already examined.
Labour Court found appellant attempted to induce Jodha Ram to destroy pages in Work Register.
Abde Ali and Trivedi authorised by Factory Manager Sri Srivastava (Ext. D39A) to conduct enquiries.
Order signed by Abde Ali and Bhagrodia (Secretary of Mills, superior to Manager, appointing/dismissing authority).
Bhagrodia deposed Srivastava authorised him during leave to pass orders based on enquiry.

legal_issues.text: Whether inquiry proceedings conducted by officers without jurisdiction under Standing Orders and in violation of principles of natural justice due to non-production of slips.
Whether discharge order dated May 3, 1963 illegal as not issued by Manager as mandatory under Standing Orders.
Whether Industrial Court exceeded jurisdiction under Sections 66/67 when interfering with Labour Court's findings.

petitioner_arguments.text: Inquiry conducted by officers (Abde Ali, Trivedi) without jurisdiction under Standing Orders; violation of natural justice as slips/gate passes not produced despite request.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Standing Orders Clause 12(4); principles of natural justice

petitioner_arguments.text: Discharge order not signed by Manager (Sri Srivastava) as required; Abde Ali competent only for inquiry, not punishment.
Industrial Court exceeded jurisdiction under Sections 66/67 by reversing Labour Court's findings in favour of appellant.
Inquiry unauthorised; mala fides and victimisation for union activities; refusal to produce documents prejudiced defence.

respondent_arguments.text: Inquiry conducted by authorised officers (Abde Ali, Trivedi) per Ext. D39A; no violation of natural justice; appellant did not request slips timely; full opportunity given; no prejudice.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Standing Orders; principles of natural justice

respondent_arguments.text: Discharge order signed by Abde Ali (authorised) and Bhagrodia (Secretary, superior authority, appointing/dismissing power; authorised by Manager during leave); valid under Standing Orders.
Labour Court erred: itself rejected mistake plea, found attempt to tamper evidence; Industrial Court justified in reversing.
No mala fides or victimisation; misconduct proved, honesty doubted.

court_reasoning.text: Abde Ali and Trivedi authorised by Manager (Ext. D39A) to conduct enquiries; concurrent findings of Labour/Industrial Courts; no violation of natural justice as appellant responsible for delayed slip request, no prejudice; Labour Court itself disbelieved mistake plea and found tampering attempt indicating guilty mind.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No violation of principles of natural justice; Industrial Court justified.

court_reasoning.text: Abde Ali authorised comprehensively, qualifies as 'Manager' under Clause 1(a); order also signed by superior Bhagrodia (appointing/dismissing authority, authorised during Manager's leave); higher authority can pass order; Labour Court overlooked this.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order passed by competent authority under Standing Orders.

court_reasoning.text: Industrial Court did not exceed jurisdiction under Sections 66/67; justified in correcting Labour Court's errors.

holdings.text: Domestic enquiry properly conducted by competent officers; no violation of natural justice.
Discharge order validly passed by competent authority (authorised officer/Manager equivalent or superior).
Industrial Court acted within jurisdiction under Sections 66/67.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Industrial Relations Act, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Approach notice requirement; jurisdiction of Industrial Court in revisions.

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of Manager under Standing Orders.

statutes_cited.name: Company Standing Orders
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for disciplinary action, inquiry, punishment; definition of Manager and authorised officers.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected all contentions of appellant-workman, upheld Industrial Court's order validating the discharge from service dated May 3, 1963; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "it is proved that he deliberately issued the additional slips, with a view to enable Bhagirath to remove extra quantity of company ash which he was not entitled to do under the contract."
key_quotes.speaker: respondent

key_quotes.text: "the plea of the appellant that he had issued the extra slips to Bhagirath due to mistake or inadvertence cannot be accepted and there is no evidence to support that plea."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court

key_quotes.text: "A person authorised by the Manager is himself a manager under Clause 1(a)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interpretation upholding authority of Abde Ali.

key_quotes.text: "there is no violation of the principles of natural justice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
